Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis, Self-assembly and Morphology Transitions in Linear and Star Polypeptide-based Block Copolymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Daniel Savin of the University of Southern Mississippi will synthesize study the interplay between the chemical composition and environment of coil-rod-coil triblock copolymers and their interchange between vesicle, disk and nanotube assemblies. The approach is to synthesize symmetric, linear triblock copolymers and three-arm star copolymers; to explore their solution self-assembly as a function of composition; to use pH and temperature to induce changes in the solution morphology of the polypeptide-based block copolymer assemblies; and to determine what factors of helix assembly, pH and temperature responsiveness dictate the interfacial curvature for block copolymer assembly into vesicles, disks or nanotubes. The broader impacts involve training graduate and undergraduate students to gain a comprehensive understanding of polymer chemistry, characterization and morphology from a fundamental and applied standpoint as well as outreach activities including the Kids' Science Challenge, web-based educational modules through NBC Learn, and the ACS Science Coaches program.

Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. Block copolymers are long chain organic molecules in which two or more chemically distinct polymer chains are attached by their ends. When a block copolymer is placed in a liquid that preferentially dissolves one of the segments, the individual chains assemble into a range of structures with nanometer scale dimensions. This work aims to enhance our fundamental understanding of the chemistry behind the block copolymer assembly process. The results of these studies could have important long term impacts on many applications including drug delivery, biosensing, pharmaceutical processing, and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The objective of the proposed research was to synthesize and characterize the solution self-assembly of linear and star triblock copolymers containing polypeptide blocks to determine how structure relates to pH-responsiveness. The primary outcomes from this project were the synthesis of novel block polymer structures that are able to assemble into elongated, and in many cases shape-changing materials: (1) ABA and BAB triblock polymers composed of poly(lysine) (PK) and poly(propylene oxide) (PPO) (i.e.: PK-PPO-PK and PPO-PK-PPO) assembled into spherical micelles at low pH and vesicles or disk micelles at high pH. (2) ABC triblock polymers composed of poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO), poly(leucine) (PL) and PK. Our initial hypothesis with PEO-PK-PL was that switching PK from charged (hydrophilic) to charge neutral (hydrophobic) would give rise to large changes in the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance, resulting in shape changes. In contrast, we found that the incorporation of PL into the triblock tends to form elongated structures, i.e.: nanotubes, branched wormlike micelles, sheet-like structures, and hydrogels. (3) m-ABC miktoarm star polymers composed of PEO, PPO and poly(glutamic acid) (PE) using a novel coupling strategy which involves the sequential addition of preformed blocks onto 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (TCT). These complex structures are pH and temperature responsive.

Throughout these studies, there were some interesting discoveries that we are using in the continued synthesis and characterization of these materials. First, we found serendipitously that we can tune the pKa of the PK block through tertiary amine formation in the side chains of the lysine units. We have always had an interest in anisotropic structures. One of the key things learned from this proposal is that using thermodynamics as a driving force can sometimes be problematic if the interactions cannot be overcome. Incorporation of PL into these block polymers is potentially interesting if you can overcome the strong hydrophobicity and tendency to assemble. As such, future work will incorporate valine and phenylalanine in PL and PIL blocks to reduce hydrophobicity.

Broader Impact: Through funding from the NSF CHE-MSN program, these novel materials have primary applications as delivery vehicles where the shape-change properties allow for controlled or targeted release under prescribed solutions.  One potential application is with delivery of cancer therapeutics. In this application, the polymer capsule will diffuse to the interior of a cancer tumor. This relies on kinetic stability of the assembly which we achieve using polymers.  Then, at the site of the tumor, the pH difference induces a shape change, releasing cargo to the specific site.  This manner of controlled release should mitigate some of the chronic and acute effects in the delivery of therapeutics. From an education and training standpoint, the program in the Savin group integrates teaching, research, and outreach in a broad range of disciplines, including chemistry, physics, biochemistry, and polymer science. Group members gain a comprehensive understanding of polymers and biomaterials in many areas of synthesis, characterization, morphology, scattering, and rheology from both a fundamental and an applied standpoint. This multidisciplinary approach is critical in training students for a variety of careers. The PI and students regularly participate in outreach activities within the department (such as the Chemathon and Molecular Mania,) and as a part of the “You are a Scientist!” outreach program to second and third grade classrooms. Overall, this project has trained six graduate students (two female, one Hispanic male, one LGBT male) and eight undergraduates (six female).


Last Modified: 11/01/2016
Modified by: Daniel A Savin
